abstract.text: Authorizes and preauthorizes rights to access a privileged operation and returns the granted rights.

inlineContent.text: Use
instead.

inlineContent.text: A pointer to a set of authorization rights you create. Pass
if the application requires no rights at this time.
A bit mask for specifying authorization options. Use the following option sets:
Pass the constant
if no options are necessary.
Specify the
mask to request rights. You can also specify the
mask to allow user interaction.
Specify the
and
masks to request partial rights. You can also specify the
mask to allow user interaction.
Specify the
and
masks to preauthorize rights.
Specify the
mask to prevent the Security framework from preserving the rights obtained during this call.

Data used when authorizing or preauthorizing rights. In macOS 10.3 and later, you can pass icon or prompt data to be used in the authentication dialog box. Possible values for this parameter are listed in
. If you are not passing any data in this parameter, pass the constant
A pointer to a newly allocated
structure. On return, this structure contains the rights granted by the Security framework. If you do not require this information, pass
. If you specify the
mask in the
parameter, the method returns all the requested rights, including those not granted, but the flags of the rights that could not be preauthorized include the
bit. Free the memory associated with this set of rights by calling the Authorization Services function
There are three main reasons to use this method. The first reason is to preauthorize rights by specifying the
, and

masks as authorization options. Preauthorization is most useful when a right has a zero timeout. For example, you can preauthorize in the application and if it succeeds, call the helper tool and request authorization. This eliminates calling the helper tool if the Security framework cannot later authorize the specified rights.
The second reason to use this method is to authorize rights before performing a privileged operation by specifying the
, and
masks as authorization options.
The third reason to use this method is to authorize partial rights. By specifying the
, and
masks as authorization options, the Security framework grants all rights it can authorize. On return, the authorized set contains all the rights.
If you do not specify the
mask and the Security framework denies at least one right, then the status of this method on return is
If you do not specify the
mask and the Security framework requires user interaction, then the status of this method on return is
If you specify the
mask and the user cancels the authentication process, then the status of this method on return is
The
parameter is not supported in OS X v10.3; use the Authorization Services function
instead. In OS X v10.3 there is an error in the signature in the header file for this parameter. If you pass this argument as (AuthorizationRights **)
, as shown in this document, it works as described.

abstract.text: A flag that instructs the Security Server to revoke authorization.
A flag that permits the Security Server to attempt to grant the rights requested.
A flag that permits user interaction as needed.
An empty flag set that you use as a placeholder when you don’t want any of the other flags.
A flag that permits the Security Server to grant rights on an individual basis.
A flag that instructs the Security Server to preauthorize the rights requested.
Frees the memory associated with a set of authorization items.
An authorization item set designated to represent a set of rights.
The user canceled the operation.
The Security Server denied authorization for one or more requested rights.
The Security Server denied authorization because no user interaction is allowed.
A constant you use in functions with an environment parameter if you have no environment data to provide.
Indicates the Security Server could not preauthorizethe right.
Restrict a user’s access to particular features in your Mac app or daemon.
A class that allows you to restrict a user’s access to particular features in your Mac app or daemon.
Authorizes and preauthorizes one specific right.
Authorizes and preauthorizes rights to access a privileged operation and returns the granted rights.
Authorizes and preauthorizes one specific right.
Authorizes and preauthorizes rights to access a privileged operation and returns the granted rights.
The flags used to specify authorization options.
An authorization item set designated to hold environment information relevant to authorization decisions.
An authorization item set designated to represent a set of rights.
